scenario:
GE Aerospace investors should focus on the operating margin for its commercial engines and services (CES) segment in 2025. The CES segment produces 6.6 times the profit of the defense & propulsion technologies (DPT) segment and guides the company's bottom line. 

In 2024, the CES segment's operating profit margin rose due to a 7.9% decline in engine production, including a 10.4% decline in LEAP engines. However, management expects a 15% to 20% growth in LEAP deliveries in 2025, which will negatively impact the CES segment's margins.

The CES segment's revenue and operating profit margin for 2024 were as follows: 
Q4 2023: $6.43 bn, 23.3% margin, $1.5 bn operating profit
Q1 2024: $6.07 bn, 23.3% margin, $1.4 bn operating profit
Q2 2024: $6.13 bn, 27.4% margin, $1.7 bn operating profit
Q3 2024: $7.0 bn, 25.7% margin, $1.8 bn operating profit
Q4 2024: $7.65 bn, 28.2% margin, $2.2 bn operating profit

GE Aerospace hopes to achieve an operating profit figure at the higher end of its guidance range of $7.6 billion to $7.9 billion for CES in 2025, assuming the services margin outperforms expectations.
